Description: Reconstructed (with added plaster) South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; top of rim glazed; exterior: lip and handle zone reserved with band between; glazed below; handles black; conical foot black on the exterior and reserved on underside.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Schlotzhauer identifies the piece as belonging to a Type 9A South Ionian cup with everted rim. The type closely follows the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18), Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-6), and Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-8). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape.
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 98-9, NAU 46, pl. 10, no. h)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 119, no. 332, pl. XXXVII)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 228, no. 142)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.275) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4820 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
